paragraphs.headline: Introduction
values: Tracking technical prospects is a critical task
Sharing those tools and making them visible is a part of being in a devleopment community.
By ensuring technology choices are visible, a dicsussion is now possible, making smart, informed choices about technology outside of an echo chamber achievable.

paragraphs.headline: What is a Technology Radar
values: A Tech Radar is an at-a-glance view of different technologies to be considered
Notes on tools, languages, frameworks, methodologies, and platforms are associated with each item.
When the degree of adoption of a technology changes, it will show up on the radar.
A radar is not an "approved list" of technologies, but instead it is a playground for discusing what is next.

quadrants.name: Languages and Frameworks
quadrants.description: Development langages (e.g. F#) and frameworks (e.g. Angular) show up here. Internal frameworks may also appear here.

quadrants.name: Tools
quadrants.description: CLI tooling (e.g. nerdctl) and desktop apps (e.g. Postman) show up here.

quadrants.name: Techniques
quadrants.description: Patterns, approaches, and best practices go here. Things such as Agile, Decorator Pattern, or Architecural Decision Records are examples.

quadrants.name: Platforms such as Azure or Confluent go here.

rings.name: Adopt
rings.description: This technology is actively being used in production today. It has a history of stability and good perfomance. New projects should consider using these technologies.

rings.name: Trial
rings.description: This technology looks hopeful. It may have been used in some PoC work and is looking for further assessment in a low-impact production project.

rings.name: Assess
rings.description: This technology looks interesting. It may have been seen on a blog or being used by another company. We want to try it out in some minor dev work and see if it may be worth using in a PoC.

rings.name: Hold
rings.description: Don't use these technologies. They aren't necessarily bad, but they may be immature, unmaintained, or simply do not align with a larger technology vision or stack. Do not use them in new projects. Consider removing them from legacy project.
